ğŸ“– Vol 1: Secrets of Prayer
The Sixth: The Odd-Numbered Prayer (Al-Witr). Anas bin Malik said: The Messenger of Allah ï·º used to perform the Odd-Numbered Prayer (Al-Witr) after the Evening Prayer (Al-'Isha) with three units of prayer (Rak'at). He would recite in the first: 'Glorify the name of your Lord, the Most High (Sabbih isma rabbika al-a'la)' and in the second: 'Say: O you who disbelieve (Qul ya ayyuha al-kafirun)' and in the third: 'Say: He is Allah, the One (Qul huwa Allahu ahad).' [225] And it came in the report that he ï·º used to pray after the Odd-Numbered Prayer (Al-Witr) two units of prayer (Rak'at) sitting, and in some of them cross-legged. [226] And in some reports: 'When he wanted to enter his bed, he would crawl to it and pray upon it two units of prayer (Rak'at) before lying down, reciting in them: 'When the earth is shaken (Idha zulzilat al-ard)' and the chapter of Abundance (Surat al-Takathur).' [227] And in another narration: 'Say: O you who disbelieve (Qul ya ayyuha al-kafirun).' And it is permissible for the Odd-Numbered Prayer (Al-Witr) to be separated and connected with one salutation (Taslimah) and two salutations (Taslimat). And the Messenger of Allah ï·º performed the Odd-Numbered Prayer (Al-Witr) with one unit of prayer (Rak'ah) [228], and three [229], and five [230], and thus with the odd-numbered prayers (Al-Awtar) up to eleven units of prayer (Rak'at) [232]. And the narration is uncertain about thirteen [233], and in a rare hadith, seventeen units of prayer (Rak'at) [234]. And these units of prayer (Rak'at), meaning what we have named in total as the Odd-Numbered Prayer (Al-Witr), are prayer at night, and it is the Vigil Prayer (Al-Tahajjud), and the Vigil Prayer (Al-Tahajjud) at night is a confirmed Sunnah, and its virtues will be mentioned in the Book of Regular Devotions (Kitab al-Awrad). And regarding the best, there is a difference of opinion. It is said that performing the Odd-Numbered Prayer (Al-Witr) with a single unit of prayer (Rak'ah) is best, since it is confirmed that he ï·º used to consistently perform the Odd-Numbered Prayer (Al-I'tar) with a single unit of prayer (Rak'ah). And it is said that the connected one is best to avoid the suspicion of disagreement, especially for the Imam, since one who does not consider the single unit of prayer (Rak'ah) as prayer may follow him. If he prays connectedly, he intends with all of them the Odd-Numbered Prayer (Al-Witr), and if he limits himself to one unit of prayer (Rak'ah) after the two units of prayer (Rak'at) of the Evening Prayer (Al-'Isha) or after the obligatory Evening Prayer (Fard al-'Isha), he intends the Odd-Numbered Prayer (Al-Witr) and it is valid because the condition of the Odd-Numbered Prayer (Al-Witr) is that it be.

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Disciplining the Soul
For preferring the worldly life (al-hayat al-dunya) is a dominant nature (tab') upon the human being, and therefore Allah the Exalted said: 'Rather, you prefer the worldly life (al-hayat al-dunya).' Then He clarified that evil is ancient in the natures (taba'i') and that this is mentioned in the previous scriptures, so He said: 'Indeed, this is in the earlier scriptures, the scriptures of Ibrahim and Musa.' This is the methodology (minhaj) of disciplining (riyada) the seeker (murid) and his upbringing (tarbiya) in gradual progression to the meeting (liqa') of Allah the Exalted.

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Status and Ostentation
And the vision (Basar) of most of creation is weak, restricted to the immediate (Al-'Ajilah) and does not extend its light to witnessing the consequences (Al-'Awaqib). Therefore, the Exalted said: 'Rather, you prefer the life of this world (Al-Hayah Al-Dunya), while the Hereafter (Al-Akhirah) is better and more lasting.' And the Mighty and Majestic said: 'No! But you love the immediate (Al-'Ajilah) and neglect the Hereafter (Al-Akhirah).' So whoever is at this limit, it is necessary to treat his heart (Qalb) from the love of status (Al-Jah) with knowledge of the immediate harms (Al-Afat Al-'Ajilah), which is to reflect on the dangers that the possessors of status (Arbab Al-Jah) are targeted with in this world (Al-Dunya). For every possessor of status is envied, intended for harm, and constantly fearful for his status and cautious lest his standing in the hearts (Qulub) changes. And hearts are more changeable than a boiling pot, wavering between acceptance (Al-Iqbal) and turning away (Al-I'rad). So whatever is built upon the hearts of creation resembles what is built upon the waves of the sea, for it has no stability. And preoccupation with observing hearts, preserving status, repelling the plotting of the envious, and preventing the harm of enemiesâ€”all of that is immediate sorrows (Ghumum 'Ajilah) and disturbs the pleasure of status. So in this world, its hoped-for does not compensate for its feared, let alone what is lost in the Hereafter. With this, the weak insight (Al-Basirah Al-Da'ifah) should be treated.

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Disciplining the Soul
For preferring the worldly life (Hayat al-Dunya) is a dominant nature (Tab') upon the human being, and therefore Allah the Exalted said: "Rather, you prefer the worldly life." Then He clarified that evil (Sharr) is ancient in the natures (Taba'i') and that this is mentioned in the previous scriptures (Kutub Salifa), so He said: "Indeed, this is in the former scriptures (Suhuf al-Ula), the scriptures of Ibrahim and Musa." This is the methodology (Manhaj) of disciplining (Riyada) the seeker (Murid) and his upbringing (Tarbiya) in gradual progression to the meeting (Liqa') with Allah the Exalted.
